stream_context.summary: Kaze reviews recent level-building progress (mainly the interior of Course 13) and spends most of the stream live-profiling Return to Yoshi’s Island with Sauraen to integrate the new F3DEX3 microcode, achieving large performance gains on real hardware while retaining emulator compatibility.

development_findings.summary: Interior platforming for Course 13 is function-complete; visual polish and enemy placement still pending.
Doors are used as hard scene boundaries so the geometry behind them can be culled until needed, improving performance.
development_findings.quote: By having a door like this, I can make it so that the room behind here doesn't render right now.

development_findings.summary: Layer 5 and Layer 6 draw orders were inverted so transparent decals render before other transparent geometry, fixing depth issues.
development_findings.quote: You have to render transparent stuff in Z order, and decals are much more likely to be behind non-decals, so we want to render the decals first.

development_findings.summary: New mechanics in Course 13 include toxic ice floors, narrowing ice paths, a far jump, a wall-kick mirror section, and slide fail-safes with healing coin lines.
Sauraen’s F3DEX3 build (LVP-NOC) replaced F3DEX2, giving ~0.8-1 ms RSP and >1 ms RDP savings per frame in Kaze’s test scene.
development_findings.quote: RDP almost a full millisecond over a full millisecond [faster].

development_findings.summary: Switching microcodes at load zones is possible; occlusion-plane variants may be used in later stages with heavy overdraw.
development_findings.quote: What you want to do is use the occlusion-plane version in a scene where overdraw is a problem… you can load a different microcode per area.

development_findings.summary: Vertex-buffer size increased from 32 to 56 vertices in EX3, avoiding redundant DMA loads and saving about 150 µs in some meshes.
Auto-batched material logic in EX3 skips redundant texture loads, cutting ~3 ms of texture time in Kaze’s ‘bunny’ stress test.
Lighting commands differ between EX2 and EX3; game code will detect emulator vs console and emit the appropriate command to stay compatible.
development_findings.quote: You need to have your game code actually send the EX2 lighting command or the EX3 lighting command based on whether this is an emulator.

development_findings.summary: Upcoming tasks: finish EX3 lighting fallback, merge custom GBI changes, implement decal Z-fighting fix, and possibly redesign armature/material workflow to reduce duplicates.
A public demo is planned ‘in a few weeks’ after Kaze’s editor finishes the next video.
development_findings.quote: My editor has been on it for a week, and after that, it's going to be the demo.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and Zeina recently became parents; their baby is currently with grandparents, freeing stream time.
context_findings.quote: The baby is currently hanging out with her grandparents.

context_findings.summary: Kaze maintains a long-term bodybuilding routine, cutting once a year; plans next cut after Christmas.
context_findings.quote: I'm kind of just in it for the long term… I usually cut like once a year.

context_findings.summary: He expresses open disdain for poorly optimized N64 games, specifically Rare titles, reflecting his performance-first design ethos.
context_findings.quote: I'm about to fail a QuickTime event and go on a full rant about how terrible Banjo-Kazooie optimizes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes turn-based JRPG pacing despite appreciating Final Fantasy VII’s atmosphere, hinting at his preference for responsive gameplay.
context_findings.quote: Goddamn, I hate JRPGs… literally 50 % of the gameplay time is just me sitting there like this.

biobak.summary: Present in chat; plans video ‘bench’ soon and notes room still feels barren; no major new art tasks mentioned this stream.

zeina.summary: Currently modeling assets for an outdoor penguin-hut village that will serve as the game’s outside hub.
zeina.quote: It will be a little village with penguin huts. Zeina is actually working on some assets for it right now.

key_stories.title: Microcode Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze invites Sauraen on stream to integrate the new F3DEX3 microcode. Through live profiling and code edits they shave over a millisecond off both RSP and RDP times, paving the way for smoother 30 FPS gameplay on real hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Return to Yoshi’s Island had become RSP-bound after extensive RDP optimizations, causing framerate drops in complex scenes.
key_stories.process: Sauraen provided a fresh EX3 branch, explained vertex-processing rewrites, command-dispatch tables, and material auto-batching; Kaze re-compiled, measured, and adjusted GBI sinks on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Performance rose enough that a formerly 28 FPS room now sustains 30 FPS; Kaze commits to EX3 for the final game.
key_stories.key_quote: With these findings I could make a banger video going ‘Everyone was wrong about the RDP, it was the RSP all along!’

key_stories.title: Designing Fair Difficulty in Course 13
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows new ice-castle sections, demonstrating safety nets like coin trails and recoverable falls to balance challenge.
key_stories.challenge: Provide late-game difficulty without punishing players unfairly.
key_stories.process: Built slide sections with healing coins, narrow paths with gradual difficulty, and mirrored wall-kick puzzles; tested live to show recovery routes.
key_stories.outcome: Stream chat agrees difficulty feels appropriate for Course 13; visuals still need polish.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the difficulty here is appropriate for CoS 13.
